Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Understanding Directionally Templated Interphase Processing-Structure Development and Relationships in Polymer Nano-Composite Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) grant provides funding for the development of a new manufacturing process that will be used to tailor polymer molecular architectures in nano-composite materials. The primary goal of this research is to apply a nano-scale templating method to the broad field of polymer-based nano-composite materials processing in order to solve key issues regarding alignment of flexible molecules by rigid nano-bodies. To understand the key scientific questions regarding how and why templating occurs, the experimental platforms of this research will focus on understanding the fundamental mechanisms associated with inducing templated structures in polymers by the nano-materials. Control of the polymer molecular alignment and shape in the composite by templating processes will also provide insight toward achieving multi-scale structural registry in the final material using a top-down processing approach. This is an issue that needs to be addressed in many fields where the material structure-property relationship is key.

If successful, the results of this research will lead to new processing approaches that can be used to control structural development in materials in order to tailor its performance. These results will also provide understanding about role of rigid nano-bodies as templates for flexible molecules in order to affect architectural control of macromolecules for materials design. This processing approach will affect materials development in many industrial areas including transportation, health care, aviation, aerospace, structural building materials, pharmaceuticals, and even sporting equipment. It will also enable fabrication of designer materials using common (i.e., cheaper) as well as more sophisticated constituents providing a new array of more affordable materials, which will in turn facilitate new technologies to be incorporated into many applications at a swifter pace.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Final Outcomes:

 

Research Outcomes:

  • This CAREER project has provided the support for fundamental understanding of the relationship between filler surface chemistry and geometry with linear polymer molecules. As a result of this new insight, this research is now moving forward into the development of processing routes for specific polymer-filler systems. Results from this work has led to the funding for new research aimed at determining a new processing routes for composite fibers by creating ‘blends’ in polymer-nano systems. This means that for the first time, specific polymer: nano-material compatible pairs may be identified. Identification of such systems will have a major impact on the process-structure-property relationships in these nanocomposite systems.
  • Over the course of this CAREER grant, out the yearly support requested for one graduate student, two graduate students in the MINUS-lab were funded at 50% time each by this project in the first two years, two student were funded fully in year three, and one student was funded in both years four and five.  The two students are working on the aspects of the project pertaining to (i) polymer/nano-carbon composites and (ii) biopolymer (collagen) synthetic processing. During all the years of the project these students receive professional development training through, research work, group meeting activities, bi-monthly one-on-one mentoring meetings with the PI (i.e., student advisor), outreach events, and conference participation. Two students completed Theses in 2017 and 2018 with significant contribution to this proposal work.
  • Over the course of this grant several undergraduate students has been provided opportunities to perform research on composite and/or bio-composite research work.  There work was partial supported by this grant (i.e., primarily in terms of materials costs) as well as with Northeastern University undergraduate research provost award funds. A total of 11 undergraduate and five (5) high school students were directly or indirectly impacted by the research for this CAREER proposal.

Educational Outcomes:

  • Participated in a “museum field trip” in July 2015 to explore the Engineering Design Challenges activity, observe visitors at this kind of open-ended inquiry-based design activity, and brainstorm ideas for an engineering-design type activity to develop around the MINUS Lab research.
  • Provided professional development in science communication and inquiry-based learning for your students via the Sharing Science Workshop & Practicum (MINUS Lab Participants: Heng, Navidad, Tina, Emily, Meng, Ying in 2014, and 2015; and Heng, Kenneth, Ying, TJ and Jess in July 2018).
  • MINUS Lab students participated in the annual Museum of Science (MOS) Boston, NanoDays outreach event and associated trainings from 2015 to 2019.
  • Worked with MOS Boston on the development of a talk for public audiences, “From Slime to Super-Fiber”, and performed this special guest researcher presentation at NanoDays 2017.  The museum also professionally filmed and edited a video of this talk and shared it on their NanoNerds YouTube Channel, as well as shared it with NSF Science 360 channel. https://youtu.be/N8Eh_LsMpW0
  • Museum hosted PI for a podcast interview about your research – which was shared on the Museum website, via iTunes, on their NanoNerds YouTube Channel and with NSF Science 360 radio. https://youtu.be/SQRR7mvW374
  • This CAREER project originally focused on developing a hands-on activity for the MOS.  However, due to the limitations in time, we did develop a museum stage presentation called “Super-powered Science” featuring the development of a CNT-polymer super-fiber. It’s currently being presented weekly on the Gordon Current Science & Technology Center stage  at the MOS Boston. To date, it’s been presented 15 times to audiences totaling 700 people and will continue to be presented throughout the Spring and Summer.
  • Developed a MEIE 6830 PhD Graduate Traineeship Course for Mechanical and Industrial Engineering Department.  To be offered Fall semesters.  The course is open to all PhD students in the College of Engineering.  The first iteration of the course is currently being taught in Fall 2019.

Modified by: Marilyn L Minus
